thread.title: "House of Cards" Star Rachel Brosnahan Says "Manhattan" Tackles Faith
thread.title_full: "House of Cards" Star Rachel Brosnahan Says "Manhattan" Tackles Faith

title: "House of Cards" Star Rachel Brosnahan Says "Manhattan" Tackles Faith
text:
"House of Cards" Star Rachel Brosnahan Says "Manhattan" Tackles Faith Posted just a moment ago 
Lionsgate (NEW YORK) -- House of Cards actress Rachel Brosnahan returned to the small screen in WGN's Manhattan, a period drama centered on the personnel at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, charged with secretly building the world's first atomic bomb. 
While the scientists of the Manhattan Project, as it was known during World War II, race to build a weapon big enough to stop Germany and Adolf Hilter, their families struggle to understand what is happening in the remote town in New Mexico. 
Brosnahan, who plays Abby Isaacs, the wife of a young scientist working on the bomb, said season two of Manhattan will touch on faith. 
"Faith is explored in a lot of ways as you can imagine when the stakes are a thousand at any given moment," she tells ABC Radio. "Everybody has a different relationship to the work they're doing there and certainly a different relationship -- or lack thereof -- to their faith." 
"For Abby, she's trying to regain control of her life and part of that becomes an exploration of her faith. In season one, after learning about the atrocities that were happening in Europe, and that she has family there, who are being persecuted because they're Jewish," Brosnahan continues. 
For the actress herself, it helped that she considers herself a spiritual person. 
"Spiritual means so many things. I happen to believe that 'religious' comes with a lot of baggage -- that word itself. But spiritual, absolutely," she says when asked. "I think anybody who believes in something strongly could be considered spiritual." 
Back on screen, Brosnahan says viewers can expect her character to have a distinct shift in how she moves around Los Alamos. 
"She arrived with absolutely no knowledge of what they were doing there at all, and what her life would be like and how it would change from what she was used to growing up in Brookline, Massachusetts. In season one, you see a very reactive Abby. Everything's being thrown at her. She's very overwhelmed. She's living moment to moment and not very successfully," she explains. "And in season two, she becomes a lot more active in this crazy and scary game that they're playing." 
Manhattan airs Tuesdays at 9 p.m. Eastern on WGN.
